title: What was the most impressive or advanced piece of Roman technology? - Quora

response.answer_text: Weirdly, Valves. Boring, simple valves. They let water out. They keep water in. So what? But the Romans, lacking machine tools and industrialized manufacturing, produced surprisingly standardized and precise in line valves to finely control the water supply to public baths, fountains and quite often, individual homes.  The design was simple, a bronze or bronze alloy junction piece with a tightly fitting plug cylinder sleeved within it. This had holes in. Turn the spindle at the top and the holes align with the pipe allowing water to pass through and vice versa.  Some modern valves you get from the hardware shop work the same way and look surprisingly similar.  Simple, but to make it work it must be robust and precisely measured. The plug insert has to be a precise fit or it will leak or Caesar up. Ahem sorry, seize up. You see, a valve isn't just a valve. If you work back through the reverse butterfly effect of what is required to make a simple device standard across a whole empire that everyone uses, you see it takes a huge amount of collective effort. We have the benefit of fine machine tools, synthetic polymers, stainless steel, a literate population that can read and count, standardized factories. Decades of craftsmen and engineers talking with each other, comparing designs, sharing best practice. You need people to travel to demonstrate to craftsmen what is required. To travel you need efficient transport, or at least roads, and therefor a robust government administration to put that in place. You have to have literacy and numeracy to a degree, otherwise you will have simply a hundred differing artistic interpretations of “valve”, not an empirical design. You need enough of the workforce producing enough of a food surplus that a segment of the population can specialize in making stuff that isn't food. Like valves. All this has to be in place first. Rome, at its heart, was a slave owning economy based on simple agriculture. Human and animal muscle power drove it, and the wind helped blow its ships. In that respect it was little different from the Minoans, Egyptians, Assyrians or any other nameless, ancient culture. And yet the pre-industrial Romans managed to coordinate themselves to such a degree that small groups of craftsmen, as far apart as northern England and Egypt, with hand tools in simple workshops, could produce a standard device that could, literally, plug into a standard plumbing system in different corners of the empire. We picture the great aqueducts sweeping into the cities dumping water into troughs while the eager plebs gather around with their buckets. In actual fact it was a lot more elegant, and indeed modern, than that.

What was the most impressive or advanced piece of Roman technology? Not the greatest, not the most advanced, and hardly the most impressive but one that really caught my attention: The Roman Multitool!  Yep, that’s a Roman multitool  Primarily designed for culinary needs, this ingenious multitool not only showed that the Romans actually had surprising skills with metal working and silver smithing, they’d decent practical-impractical imagination! A couple of things, the ROMAN designers of that thing were a lot brighter than their modern counter parts. Note this flipper/fork, the length. It was workable for actually cooking food on a fire without getting burned, as one might do in the field, or near a campfire.  Compare that practical design with the near worthless for actual camp fire cooking fork, knife and spoon set below.  Now I just know that someone out there is going to say the eyeball rolling ‘they didn’t know about forks back then.’  People who knew about tridents could figure out a fork.  Only some of my Northern European ancestors seemed to have missed that one, for a while.  or so we believe.  some of my other ancestors used these:  I guess my earliest ancestors used these:

Now that I’ve gotten three requests to answer this…. I’m going to go domestic rather than urban; city-wise, aqueducts and the arches that made them possible were definitely the most impressive. But for living in a nice house, they came up with this:  It was called a hypocaust, and as far as anyone knows it was the original floor heating — not with air blown up through vents, but actually heating the floor. Of course the system did more than just heat the floor itself; the pillars that supported the floor got heated up as well, as to an extent so did the walls because the exhaust from the furnace flowed up through the walls. Since the whole structure was stone and/or brick, plus mortar of course, once the floor was nice and warm the stone itself held enough heat that it radiated evenly, and once the walls got warm the building could hold the heat quite a while even if the fire went out.
To my mind, the dome of the Pantheon. To this day, at 43 metres (142 ft) in diameter, it’s still the largest unsupported/un-reinforced concrete dome in the world - and it’s about 2,000 years old!

Everyone has their own favorite — and I’ll be first to admit that the other answers merit awe and respect. For me, I was impressed by the fact that the Romans had created “factory complexes” that used water-power to drive hydraulic stone-cutting saws, milling machines, leather-pounding machines, and all at one site!

The Greatest Roman achievement undoubtedly was building the largest world empire and controlling it for 1000 years, each side :-), West and East.  Military innovation, logistics, the training of Marius' mules - all this made the Roman legions unstopable war machines.🙏

Arches. The Romans were the first builders in Europe, perhaps the first in the world, to fully appreciate the advantages of the arch, the vault and the dome.[1] So, the Romans didn’t invent the arch but they went all out with it for practical nation-building uses.  Footnotes[1] Arch - Wikipedia

The question is difficult since the Roman philosophy was Adopt, Adapt, Improve. So the vast majority of things the Romans did for us were things others had already done but which the Romans did so much better! Take the aqueduct - by no means their inventio - but have you seen some of theirs!?  Segovia.
Water setting concrete. Concrete, itself, was impressive, but the invention of water setting concrete allowed construction of massive underwater structures that remain existing even today.
The Codex, or bound book. Quite an advancement from scrolls & stone tablets. The concrete arch is a close 2nd.
